de.esoco.lib.expression.monad

Class Try<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.expression.monad.Try<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Functor<T>, Monad<T,Try<?>>

    public abstract class Try<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Monad<T,Try<?>>
    A Monad implementation for the attempted execution of value-supplying operations that may fail with an exception. Whether the execution was successful can be tested with isSuccess().

    Executions can be performed in two different ways: either immediately by creating an instance with now(ThrowingSupplier) or lazily with lazy(ThrowingSupplier). In the first case the provided supplier will be evaluated upon creation of the try instance. In the case of lazy executions the supplier will only be evaluated when the Try is consumed by invoking one of the corresponding methods like Functor.orUse(Object) or Functor.orFail(). This will also be the case for mapped lazy tries. A side effect of this is that lazy tries may appear as not complying with the monad laws, although effectively they are (see method comment of lazy(ThrowingSupplier) for details).

    The supplier of a try, even of a lazy one, is always only evaluated once. Each subsequent consumption will yield the same result. If a supplier should be re-evaluated on each call the Call monad can be used instead.

      • lazy

        public static <T> Try<T> lazy(de.esoco.lib.expression.ThrowingSupplier<T> fSupplier)
        Returns a new instance that will perform a lazy evaluation of the given supplier. That means the supplier will only be queried if one of the consuming methods like Functor.orUse(Object) is invoked to access the result. Mapping or flat mapping a lazy try will create another unresolved, lazy instance.

        A side effect of lazy tries not evaluating the argument supplier immediately is that an unresolved lazy try does not directly comply with the monad laws. This is because when (flat) mapped additional wrapping suppliers will be created that will also be evaluated lazily. Until resolving tests between otherwise identical lazy tries will fail because the created lambdas will not be recognized as equal. Resolved lazy tries obey the monad laws, so lazy tries are effectively compliant with the laws. Equality tests should therefore only be used with caution on lazy tries (or better, not at all).

        An instance that evaluates the supplier immediately and directly obeys the monad laws can be created with now(ThrowingSupplier).

        Parameters:
        fSupplier - The throwing supplier to evaluate lazily
        Returns:
        The new instance

      • now

        public static <T> Try<T> now(de.esoco.lib.expression.ThrowingSupplier<T> fSupplier)
        Returns a new instance that represents the immediate execution of the given Supplier. The returned instance either represents a successful execution or a failure if the execution failed.

        An instance that evaluates the supplier lazily on the first access can be created with lazy(ThrowingSupplier).

        Parameters:
        fSupplier - The supplier to execute
        Returns:
        The new instance

      • ofAll

        public static <T> Try<java.util.Collection<T>> ofAll(java.util.Collection<Try<T>> rTries)
        Converts a collection of attempted executions into either a successful try of a collection of values if all tries in the collection were successful or into a failed try if one or more tries in the collection have failed. The error of the failure will be that of the first failed try.

        Other than ofSuccessful(Stream) this transformation cannot be performed on a stream (of possibly indefinite size) because success or failure needs to be determined upon invocation.

        Parameters:
        rTries - The collection of tries to convert
        Returns:
        A new successful try of a collection of the values of all tries or a failure if one or more tries failed

      • ofSuccessful

        public static <T> Try<java.util.stream.Stream<T>> ofSuccessful(java.util.stream.Stream<Try<T>> rTries)
        Converts a stream of attempted executions into a try of a stream of successful values.
        Parameters:
        rTries - The stream of tries to convert
        Returns:
        A new try that contains a stream of successful values

      • run

        public static Try<java.lang.Void> run(de.esoco.lib.expression.ThrowingRunnable fCode)
        Returns a new instance that represents the immediate execution of the given Runnable. The returned instance either represents a successful execution or a failure if the execution failed.

        Because a runnable doesn't return a value the generic type of the result is VOID and consequently the wrapped value is NULL. Therefore mapping or consuming the returned instance doesn't make sense. The main purpose of this method is to serve as a compact alternative to try/catch blocks, like in this example:

        Try.run(() -> invokeWithPossibleFailure()).orElse(e -> handleError(e));
        Parameters:
        fCode - The code to execute
        Returns:
        The new instance

        Parameters:

      • flatMap

        public abstract <R,N extends Monad<R,Try<?>>> Try<R> flatMap(java.util.function.Function<? super T,N> fMap)
        Maps this instance into another monad by applying a mapping function to the enclosed value that produces the new monad. Implementations should override the return type to their specific type because the Java type system provides no way to generically define the method return type needed for this case.
        Specified by:
        flatMap in interface Monad<T,Try<?>>
        Parameters:
        fMap - The monad mapping function
        Returns:
        The mapped and flattened monad

      • isSuccess

        public abstract boolean isSuccess()
        Checks whether the execution was successful.
        Returns:
        TRUE if this try was executed successfully, FALSE if an exception occurred

      • and

        public <V,R,N extends Monad<V,Try<?>>> Try<R> and(N rOther,
                                                  java.util.function.BiFunction<? super T,? super V,? extends R> fJoin)
        Combines this monad with another monad into a new monad of the same type. This is done by invoking Monad.flatMap(Function) on this instance and "lifting" the other monad by invoking it's Monad.map(Function) method. Therefore this type of method is sometimes also called "lift" or "liftM2".

        Implementations should override this method to return their own type but they can simply invoke the default implementation ( Monad.super.and(rOther, fJoin)) and cast the result to their own type. The explicit declaration in subclasses is necessary because of the limitations of Java's generic type system.

        Specified by:
        and in interface Monad<T,Try<?>>
        Parameters:
        rOther - The other monad to combine with
        fJoin - A binary function that joins the values of both monads
        Returns:
        The new joined monad

      • filter

        public Try<T> filter(java.util.function.Predicate<T> pCriteria)
        Filter this try according to the given criteria by returning a try that is successful if this try is successful and the wrapped value fulfills the criteria, or a failure otherwise.
        Parameters:
        pCriteria - A predicate defining the filter criteria
        Returns:
        The resulting try
